div.l: And hardily þei dorst ley her nekke
Þe Miller shuld not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn ne be sleight ne be force hem Reue
And atte last þe wardeyn ȝaue hem leue
Joh hieght þat oon and Aleyn hight þat oþ̉er
Of oon town were thei born þat heght strother
Fer in þe Northt I con nouȝt telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy Alle his gere
And on a hors þe sak he cast a noon
Forth goth Aleyn þe clerke and Also John
With goode swird ⁊and with bokeler by his side
John knew þe wai hym nedid no gide
And atte þe Mylne þe sak doun he layth
Aleyn spake first Al hail symoıı̄un in faith
How fares þi faire doughter and þi wif
Aleyn welcome qduod Symkyn be my lif
And John Also how now what do ȝe here
By god qduod John Symond nede has no pere
Hym by houes serue hym self þat hath no swayn
Or elles he is a fool as clerkes sayn
Oure Manciple I hope he wil be dede
Swa wyrkes hym ay þe wanges in his hede
And þerfore is I come and eke Aleyn
To grynde oure corne and carie it home agoyn
I pray ȝow spede vs hethen þat ȝe may
It shal be don̄ qduod Symkyn be my faie
What wil ȝe don̄ þᵗat wile it is in honde
By god right by the hoper wil I stonde
Quod Iohn and see ho gates þᵉ corn gose in
Ȝet saugh I neuer by my fader kynne
How þat þe hoꝑper wagges to ⁊and fro
Aleyn vnswarid John wil þow so
Then wil I be by neith be my croune
And se how gates þe mele falles a doune
In to þe trough þat shal be my disporte
Quod Iohn in faith I may be of ȝoure sorte
I is as ille a Myller as ere ȝe
This Miller smylet of her nycete
